title: ECU Joondalup SC
text:
The ECU Joondalup Soccer Club is an Australian <a href="association%20football">soccer</a> club from <a href="Joondalup%2C%20Western%20Australia">Joondalup, Western Australia</a> currently playing in the <a href="National%20Premier%20Leagues%20Western%20Australia">National Premier Leagues Western Australia</a>.
Their home ground is the ECU Football Stadium at the Joondalup campus of <a href="Edith%20Cowan%20University">Edith Cowan University</a>, which the club is now named after.
History.
The ECU Joondalup Soccer Club was formed in 1992 as Joondalup City Soccer Club and played at the Gumblossom Park in <a href="Quinns%20Rocks">Quinns Rocks</a>. They moved to the <a href="Arena%20Joondalup">Arena Joondalup</a> in 1995 and in their first season in the <a href="Football%20West%20State%20League">Semi-pro league</a> finished third in the Professional Soccer Federation of WA third division a great start to top-flight <a href="association%20football">football</a> in the state.
In the first season of the Soccer West Coast Division One, City won promotion to the <a href="Football%20West%20State%20League">Premier League</a> as Champions in 1996. Joondalup City's first season in the top flight in 1997 was a moderately successful one, where they finished in a mid-table position and improved to third place in 1998.
In 1999 the club changed its name to ECU Joondalup and a successful season saw Paul Simmons' side win the club's first major trophy by taking out the <a href="Football%20West%20State%20League">Premier League</a> title, which was their first-ever Premiership after only four seasons in the professional ranks.
Under the guidance of former <a href="Perth%20Glory%20FC">Perth Glory</a> manager <a href="Kenny%20Lowe">Kenny Lowe</a>, ECU Joondalup won their first Championship in 2020 (no Premier was awarded), with striker Danny Hodgson also claiming the season's Golden Boot award with 17 goals.
Notable past players.
List includes players from ECU Joondalup youth or senior teams that have gone on to represent the <a href="Australia%20national%20soccer%20team">Australian national team</a>.
